timeline.bodyText:
I think I'd keep SpanWithScope out of this this new API, and have HttpServerTracer return and work only on spans.
SpanWithScope is primarily an auto-instrumentation detail to make it easier to pass them both between @OnMethodEnter and @OnMethodExit (in the future we could potentially get rid of it altogether using an extra @Local bytebuddy parameter, reducing memory allocations).
timeline.author: trask

And that scope incapsulates a span which may be different from the returned value. If we don't need this "rescoping" then things become easier.

replies.bodyText:
E.g. in case of async servlet request processing we create span for incoming request in one thread, but actual request continues processing happens in another thread.
Depending on servlet container implementation, this processing may again arrive into this method.
E.g. Jetty handles async requests in a way that calls HttpServlet.service method twice.

Other http servers don't do this weird thing of calling the same entrypoint for a second time from another thread
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText: Current comment brings Jetty example only because I have personally seen this effect in Jetty. I have currently no idea if other containers can lead to the same effect. In master this rescoping logic lives in Servlet3Advice, which is servlet-container agnostic. I can move rescoping back there to preserve the current status quo.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText: But coming back to you original request in this thread. Do you propose that tracers should only concern themselves with spans and not scopes? For me managing scope (aka "what is the current span") is a cross-cutting concern that we should, ideally, handle centrally. And not in every single instrumentation. If you don't want to do it here, then what common code will handle #465 ? I thought this tracer is a good place for that.
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
My current thoughts:

Have HttpServerTracer.startSpan() just create a new span (no conditional logic whether to create it or not, and no attaching to scope)
Have a separate method that we call beforehand: HttpServerTracer.shouldCreateSpan(...) --> boolean, which can check the SERVER attribute in the current context
Have another method that we call afterwards: HttpServerTracer.withSpan(Span) --> Scope, which can set the span in the SERVER attribute and attach the scope
Ya, let's leave that rescoping logic only in Servlet3Advice, I don't think it's needed anywhere else

Some additional background:

I don't particularly like SpanWithScope, it was basically just a workaround for passing both of those objects between @OnMethodEnter and @OnMethodExit, and at some point I'd like to get rid of SpanWithScope, instead adding a ByteBuddy @Local parameter to carry Span and Scope separately between @OnMethodEnter and @OnMethodExit
I like being explicit about Scope/Context, and think it's ok to have a couple extra method calls to keep this more explicit
replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText:
Your suggestion looks good, I will try it. But it defeats one of my goals: to remove "constant call chains", where every instrumentation has to call exact same methods in exact same sequence.
But I will try first removing rescoping and will see how code will look like then.

replies.author: trask

replies.bodyText:
Adding this logic (checking isCommitted) should make the response code in the Span align with the response code received by the client, no?

I think not. We read status code from the response. Then if that status code is not 200 and exception was thrown, then we set http.status_code attribute value to 500. But we don't change response status code in HttpResponse object. So client will still get 200. Or am I wrong?
replies.author: iNikem

replies.bodyText:
Ah, no, this part of the servlet spec is defining how servlet containers behave:

If the exception isn't caught and handled, and the response hasn’t been committed, the status code MUST be set to 500

So if an exception is thrown, and the response has not been committed, the servlet container will change the response code to 500 and the client will get 500.
